official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of Agriculture to publish in the Federal Register a strategy to
			 significantly increase the role of volunteers and partners in National
			 Forest System trail maintenance, and for other purposes.

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds as follows:

features a world-class trail system with over 158,000 miles of trails

			 hunting, mountain bicycling, motorized vehicles, and other outdoor
			 activities.

header.#text: National forest system trails volunteer and partnership strategy

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall publish in
			 the Federal Register a strategy to significantly increase the role of
			 volunteers and partners in trail maintenance.

text.#text: Not later than 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Forest System Trails Stewardship Act of 2014/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: The strategy required by

augment and support the capabilities of Federal employees to carry out or contribute to trail
			 maintenance;

provide meaningful opportunities for volunteers and partners to carry out trail maintenance in each
			 region of the

address the barriers to increased volunteerism and partnerships in trail maintenance identified by
			 volunteers, partners, and others;

prioritize increased volunteerism and partnerships in trail maintenance in those regions with the
			 most severe trail maintenance needs, and where trail maintenance backlogs
			 are jeopardizing access to National Forest lands; and

aim to increase trail maintenance by volunteers and partners by 100 percent by the date that is 5
			 years after the date of the enactment of this Act.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall study opportunities to improve trail
			 maintenance by addressing opportunities to use fire crews in trail
			 maintenance activities in a manner that does not jeopardize firefighting
			 capabilities, public safety, or resource protection. Upon a determination
			 that trail maintenance would be advanced by use of fire crews in trail
			 maintenance, the

shall incorporate these proposals into the
			 strategy, subject to such terms and conditions as the

determines
			 to be necessary.

text.#text: As a component of the strategy, the

quote.#text: , including a volunteer affiliated with a partner organization,

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall adopt
			 regulations implementing this section. These regulations shall ensure that
			 the financial risk from claims or liability associated with volunteers
			 undertaking trail maintenance is shared by all administrative units.

text.#text: Not later than 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall develop the strategy in consultation with volunteer and partner trail
			 maintenance organizations, a broad array of outdoor recreation
			 stakeholders, and other relevant stakeholders.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall require each administrative unit to develop a volunteer and partner
			 coordination implementation plan for the strategy which clearly defines
			 roles and responsibilities for the administrative unit and district staff,
			 and includes strategies to ensure sufficient coordination, assistance, and
			 support for volunteers and partners to improve trail maintenance.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall prepare a report on—

the effectiveness of the strategy in addressing the trail maintenance backlog;

the increase in volunteerism and partnership efforts on trail maintenance as a result of the
			 strategy;

trails maintained by volunteers and partners, and the
			 approximate value of the volunteer and partnership efforts;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall select no fewer than 9 and
			 no more than 15 priority areas for increased trail maintenance
			 accomplishments.

text.#text: In accordance with

Priority areas shall include a well-defined region on National Forest System land where the lack of
			 trail maintenance has—
reduced access to public land;
led to an increase, or risk of increase, in harm to natural resources;
jeopardized public safety;
resulted in trails being impassible by the intended managed users; or
increased future deferred trail maintenance costs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: In selecting priority areas, the

consider any public input on priority areas received within 3 months of the date of enactment of
			 this Act; and
select at least one priority area in each region of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and in accordance with
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Forest System Trails Stewardship Act of 2014/s:5/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Forest System Trails Stewardship Act of 2014/s:5/ss:d/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall develop an approach to substantially
			 increase trail maintenance accomplishments within each priority area.

text.#text: Within 6 months of the selection of priority areas under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Forest System Trails Stewardship Act of 2014/s:5/ss:d/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: In developing the approach under
consider any public input on trail maintenance priorities and needs within any priority area;
consider the costs and benefits of increased trail maintenance within each priority area; and
incorporate partners and volunteers in the trail maintenance.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Forest System Trails Stewardship Act of 2014/s:5/ss:d/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall substantially increase
			 trail maintenance within each priority area.

text.#text: Utilizing the approach developed under

The regional volunteer and partnership coordinators may be responsible for assisting partner
			 organizations in developing and implementing volunteer and partnership
			 projects to increase trail maintenance within priority areas.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall periodically review the priority areas to determine whether revisions are
			 necessary and may revise the priority areas, including the selection of
			 new priority areas or removal of existing priority areas, at his sole
			 discretion.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may enter into a cooperative agreement (within the meaning of

) with any State, tribal, local governmental, and
			 private entity to carry out this Act.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/31/63

text.#text: The
Cooperative agreements authorized under this section may—
improve trail maintenance in a priority area;
implement the strategy; or
advance trail maintenance in a manner deemed appropriate by the

header.#text: Stewardship credits for outfitters and guides

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall establish a pilot program on not less than 20
			 administrative units to offset all or part of the land use fee for an
			 outfitting and guiding permit by the cost of the work performed by the
			 permit holder to construct, improve, or maintain National Forest System
			 trails, trailheads, or developed sites that support public use under terms
			 established by the

text.#text: Within 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, in accordance with this section, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Forest System Trails Stewardship Act of 2014/s:7/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: In establishing the pilot program authorized by
select administrative units where the pilot program will improve trail maintenance; and
establish appropriate terms and conditions.
